title: That Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm I Tried: My Skin Got Weirdly Happy
body:
Okay so I’m just gonna talk about this beef tallow stuff. I know. It sounds insane. Beef fat. On your face. I was scrolling Etsy one night, it was late, my heater was making that clicking sound it does, and my hands looked like old parchment. Saw this thing called “Whipped Tallow Balm - Bourbon Vanilla.” My first thought was literally, “What.” My second thought was, “That’s a thing people do?” But I clicked. The pictures looked nice. The description said it was for winter skin. I was desperate. My knuckles were cracking. So I ordered it. A little jar from some shop in France. Figured if it was gross, I’d just hide it in the back of a drawer.

Anyway it showed up like two weeks later. A small jar. I opened it. Smelled like. I don’t know. Nice though. Not like beef. Not like a steak. Like vanilla maybe? But not candle vanilla. More like. You know when you bake something and the kitchen just feels good? That. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was solid but soft. Like if cold butter and whipped cream had a baby. I poked it. I was still skeptical. I mean, come on. Tallow? For skin? But my elbows were so rough they were catching on my sweater. So I tried it.

## How I Started Putting Beef Fat on My Face

Look, I had to look this up because I felt ridiculous. Why would this work? So I fell down a internet hole for an hour. Turns out, it’s not that new. My grandma probably knew about it. People have been using animal fats on skin for, like, forever. Lard, tallow, all that. The science-y bit, the way I get it, is that grass-fed beef tallow is kinda similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it doesn’t just sit on top like some lotions that feel slick. It actually sinks in. It’s like giving your skin something it already recognizes. That made a weird amount of sense to me. My skin was freaking out because winter air is mean and my fancy lotion from the drugstore wasn’t cutting it. It was just putting a wet blanket on a fire. This tallow balm thing was more like adding the right kind of wood.

So I started using it. Just on my hands at first. After washing dishes. The water here is so hard, it’s like liquid sandpaper. I’d scoop a tiny bit, rub it between my palms. It melts real fast from your body heat. Goes from that firm texture to almost nothing. Then you just… put it on. It didn’t feel greasy after a minute. Just soft. Not “slippery doorknob” soft. Just normal skin soft. My cuticles stopped looking angry. The cracks on my knuckles actually started to close up. I was shocked. I didn’t expect anything. I expected to be wiping beef grease off on my jeans.

## What This Bourbon Vanilla Stuff Actually Does

The scent is the best part, I won’t lie. It’s not a perfume smell. It’s a comfort smell. It’s that bourbon vanilla they talk about. Warm. Not sugary. Like a vanilla bean pod, not a cupcake. It’s cozy. I put it on before bed sometimes and it’s just… nice. It doesn’t give me a headache. It just smells like a calm evening. Which, in January, is a big deal. My whole mood is better when I’m not scratching my dry patches.

So then I got brave. I used it on my face. I have this one spot near my eyebrow that gets so dry it flakes. I put a tiny, tiny amount there. And on my cheeks. It absorbed. No breakout. No weird pore situation. My skin just felt… quiet. Hydrated but not shiny. I started using it after I shower. My legs get so itchy in winter, it’s maddening. This stuff stopped the itch. It’s like it told my skin to relax. I keep the jar on my nightstand now. It’s become a thing. The whole ritual of it. The simple ingredients list. It’s just grass-fed beef tallow, some oils, and that vanilla. No words I can’t pronounce. That matters to me, I guess. I’m tired of buying potions with fifty ingredients that do nothing.

Oh, and my lips. Chapped lips are the worst. I used a dab on them. Game changer. Better than any waxy stick I’ve bought. It just sinks in and repairs. I sound like an ad. I’m not. I’m just a person whose skin was miserable and now it’s not. The Etsy shop I got it from, their whole deal is just making this one thing really well. You can tell. It’s not fancy packaging. It’s just good stuff inside.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Experiment

So it’s been maybe a month now. I’m almost halfway through the jar. I use it every day. The results are… they’re not dramatic in a “wow you look 20 years younger” way. They’re dramatic in a “my skin doesn’t hurt anymore” way. That’s bigger, honestly. The relief is real. My hands are presentable. My face doesn’t feel tight. That winter redness on my cheeks has calmed down. I don’t think about my skin all day. That’s the biggest win. Before, I was constantly aware of the dry spots, the itch, the discomfort. Now I just forget. It’s just my skin, doing its thing, being fine.

I told my sister about it. She has eczema on her hands sometimes. She was even more skeptical than me. “You’re putting what on your face?” But she tried some of mine. Texted me two days later: “Okay what’s that stuff called again.” That’s the best review, right? When someone who thinks you’re nuts asks for the link.

I’m gonna order another jar soon. Before I run out. I don’t want to be without it. It’s become my winter security blanket. For all the weirdness of the concept—rubbing rendered beef fat into your skin—the reality is just simple, effective comfort. It’s like the skincare version of a worn-in sweatshirt. It just works. I don’t have a better explanation.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. From what I read, grass-fed beef tallow has fats that are really compatible with our skin. It’s not as weird as it sounds. It’s more like giving your skin something it knows how to use, instead of a synthetic thing it has to figure out.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores. Because it’s so similar to our own sebum, it seems to absorb properly instead of sitting on top and blocking things. A little goes a long way, though. You don’t need a huge glob.

**What does the Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s a warm, cozy vanilla. Not a sweet bakery smell. More like the scent of a vanilla bean. It’s gentle and comforting, not overpowering at all. It fades to just a faint, nice skin smell after a little while.

Anyway. If your skin is throwing a fit because of the cold, and the usual stuff isn’t helping, this might be worth a weird shot. It was for me. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.
